petitioner.name: ALBERTO R. GONZALES, ATTORNEY GENERAL, ET AL.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: The Court will now hear argument in Gonzales v. Oregon. General Clement.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: May I ask, what Federal law does it violate?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, now, would that be true also for any doctor who provided the substances to furnish  an execution of a convicted death penalty convict?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: But, otherwise, it would be the same reasoning --

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: But would it be open --

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: -- to the Attorney General to pass a regulation like this one, and all of a sudden apply it -- some new Attorney General, who had a very different view of the death penalty?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Does the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, not if it just refers back to the States, would it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Does the statute -- does the Federal statute specifically authorize doctors to do this? Or does it simply say that convicts may be executed by lethal injection?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: No, but the method may simply be lethal injection.  And, going back to Justice O'Connor's question, it might still be the case that, on the theory the Government is advancing this morning, it would be unlawful for a doctor to engage in that, because  that was, in fact, not within the limits of the practice of medicine, the doctor was using a controlled substance for something outside the practice of medicine, and hence, it would be illegal.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But I take it Congress did not refer specifically to -- or did not include a specific authorization of doctors, so that we'd have to do a little construction to get to your point.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: In your view, were it not for the statute, the Federal statute, your view of the Attorney General's authority is -- leaving that statute aside, if it weren't there -- the Attorney General, should we have an Attorney General who is opposed to the death penalty, could, in fact, regulate or stop Federal -- State death penalties, through this same mechanism, by saying that no physician can be registered insofar as he engages in that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: At most, it --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- at most, it would allow him to prosecute, or to move for the dis-certification of doctors who engage in that practice.  And if the State chooses to do it without doctors, it would be okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, what we're getting -- at least what I'm getting at was this is, I would probably have read the statute to say that the drug statute, which is trying to stop drug addiction and heroin and -- has nothing to do with the death penalty.  And I would think that the argument on the other side is that the statute has nothing to do with assisted suicide.  Congress didn't think about the death penalty, and it didn't think about assisted suicide.  It's rather like the tobacco case, except a fortiori.  Now, what's your response to that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: May I comment --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: May I --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- may I ask you about the position this Court took in Glucksberg?  That is, everyone on the Court in that case seemed to assume that physician- assisted suicide was a matter for the State, and the Government, at that time, said, "State legislatures undoubtedly have the authority to create the kind of exception to assisted suicide fashioned by the court of appeals.  There is every reason to believe that State legislatures will address the urgent issues involved in this case in a fair and impartial way."  And then the Government added that, "There is no indication that the political processes are malfunctioning in this area." That was a position presented to this Court in the Glucksberg case by the Government. Now, you are rejecting that position.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, they say --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- that, in practical terms, that is exactly what it does, because the only way they can administer their law sensibly is by using these kinds of drugs, scheduled drugs.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, did he use --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- did he use a controlled substance?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But we're told that the -- those methods are less gentle to the patient, the methods that the State of Oregon has authorized its physicians to prescribe.  We are told, at least in some of the briefs, that, from the patient's point of view, it's much less upsetting.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: General Clement --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But Congress --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- Congress spoke --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- Congress spoke about section -- schedule 1 drugs, and that's what's lacking here.  Congress says schedule 1 drugs, those are: no, never; schedule 2: okay on a doctor's prescription.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: General Clement, before you go there, I want to question you about your distinction between Dr. Kevorkian and a doctor who uses controlled substances.  Why could not the Attorney General treat Dr. Kevorkian's conduct as conduct that may threaten the public health and safety, and seek his -- cancellation of his license?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Well, he --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- he can rely --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- on things like prior convictions, other things unrelated to a specific transaction.  And if he thinks that assisted suicide is contrary conduct that threatens the public interest, health and safety, I don't know why that wouldn't apply to Dr. Kevorkian, as well as somebody using controlled substances.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But the Attorney General's directive, if I remember it, does not identify any particular controlled substance.  It just identified a particular kind of conduct by the doctor.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Neither one.  Neither one is identifying which schedule 2 or schedule 3 substance may not be used.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, for me --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- for me, the case turns on the statute.  And it's a hard case.  And it seems to me that your answer to Justice Stevens would be to say that the Justice Department has found this practice to be an abuse of the drug.  But then, my question -- and if -- if you had, in fact, given that answer, my question -- [Laughter.]

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- my question would then be, Isn't that an odd statutory scheme, where the Attorney General can find it to be an abuse of the use of the drug if the State of Oregon has specifically told its doctors, under special procedures in defined circumstances, that they can administer it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, that's --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- that's -- that's a -- the slipper-slope argument that I wanted to explore a bit.  If we do rule against you, and for the State of Oregon, on the statute, you do think that there will be some other serious consequence which will hinder the Department of Justice in an orderly implementation of this statute, particularly under the abuse formulation?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But part --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- part of the regime referred to under the statute -- and it's 801(a) implementing the convention on psychotropic drugs -- and there, the implementation incorporates the treaty -- but it says that, "This shall not displace the judgment of the medical  -- community, as determined by the Secretary."  And it seems to me that that cuts against you in this case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, certainly the practice of medicine by physicians is an area traditionally regulated by the States, is it not?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: And there is nothing express in the statute suggesting that it's designed to put in the hands of the Federal Government or the Attorney General the regulation of the practice of medicine, is there?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, and there were two attempts, were there not, to get legislation passed to do this expressly in Congress, and they failed?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: And a prior Attorney General had a different interpretation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Yeah, but --

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: -- are these -- are these drugs classified as illegal, for all purposes?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: No.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Yeah, but it's a --

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: -- it's a different thing to regulate by saying, "No one can prescribe this substance. It's so lethal, we won't let anyone prescribe it at all."  And it's quite different to say, "This -- if a -- if a physician follows the Oregon law, it's a -- it's not a legitimate practice of medicine."  That's a very different approach.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Yeah.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- what is the closest analog you have, outside of the present case, where the Attorney General's enforcement activity has impinged upon what the State has recognized as medical practice?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, that's the FDA. I'm talking about the Attorney General, under this statute.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: No, but --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- that was a clear act of Congress.  I mean, Congress had made that decision, and it was unmistakable.  It seems to me that the problem that you have, with your reference back to the Harrison Act and the 90 years of regulation, is that the 90 years of regulation was regulation for the purpose of stopping drug  pushing and drug abuse, in the conventional sense.  And to say that a statute -- or a statutory history taken into consideration in determining the scope of this statute, with that kind of a history, can support a view that suddenly the Attorney General of the United States is given, in effect, the sole authority to determine whether any State may or may not authorize assisted suicide, and may do so in a way that any other Attorney General can flip back and forth -- as has happened in this case, if Attorney General Reno was wrong -- seems to me a kind of argument from history that simply cuts against you, because it leads to a sort of a bizarre result.  I mean, what is your response to that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, and I -- as I said, it seems to me that your 91 years of history say that the end that Congress had in mind was to stop drug pushing and stop conventional drug abuse.  It didn't have any more -- there's no indication that I know of that Congress had assisted suicide in mind, any more than it had the administration of the death penalty in mind.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Suicide is a result of the kind of dementia that comes from drug abuse.  That is not suicide under the circumstances that we're talking about within the limits of the Oregon law.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: General, then may I just ask this question?  We're focusing on whether congress really authorized this action by the Attorney General.  And in the Raich case, which, of course, was a close case -- there were three dissents in the case -- the -- there was great attention on the fact Congress had considered the interstate market for the product involved, an impact on the market if it was allowed to be sold in -- or grown and so forth in California.  But is there any evidence at all that Congress thought that any of these -- schedule 2 or 3 substances that are used in assisted-suicide situations -- that Congress focused on the impact of that use on the interstate market for those drugs?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But are they --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- are they transactions that  have any impact on any market, any commercial market, that Congress ever mentioned?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Why were -- you were going to say, at one point -- why was Congress concerned about overdoses of narcotics and so forth?  Why?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But, I mean, there was a reason, wasn't there, that they're worried about people taking narcotics?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Right.  What was the main --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I would have thought it was narcotics addiction.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right.  Well, if it is narcotics addiction --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- and I would have thought  that was it --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right.  All right.  Again, because you know I'm going to say, What has this got to do with that?  So, why not solely? [Laughter.]

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Not solely.  You go ahead. What else?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes.  Yes, but it's true addiction.  And this seems to --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Yeah, but even in your example, the concern of Congress is with the use of the drug to hurt people who do not understand that they're going to be hurt, and don't want to be hurt, and perhaps, in your example, the use of the drug to facilitate the violation of the law, that seems to me worlds away from what we're talking about here.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, General Clement. Mr. Atkinson. ON BEHALF OF RESPONDENTS

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Would you speak up just a little, please?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Maybe elevate your -- the microphone.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Maybe you could raise the podium.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You're too tall. [Laughter.]

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Raise it up.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: No, that -- the crank will raise it, if you -- no, the other way around. Thank you.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, the relationship between the States and the Federal Government has changed a little since Gibbons versus Ogden. [Laughter.]  --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, that begs the question -- if you had said "this specific subject," the regulation of controlled substances, your answer would have come out the other way, which is kind of what the case is about.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes, because, I mean, wouldn't -- suppose that some State said that, "We think doctors can prescribe, for people who want to take it, morphine for recreational use."

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No matter what?  I mean, they have cases and so forth that say, "Of course a State could go too far.  A State might decided it's" -- just what I said.  And you're going to say your case turns or falls -- you win or lose, depending on whether I accept that a State could not stop a doctor from becoming, in effect, a conduit to a group of drug dealers by saying, "I think recreational use is part of my medical practice"?  That would be up to the State?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: No, it didn't "stop it" --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- but could the State allow it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And if the State allowed it, the Federal Government would have to allow the drugs to be used for that purpose --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- you're saying.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I would have thought that at the time this legislation was enacted, it would have been as unthinkable for a State to allow drugs to be used -- to be prescribed by a doctor to kill a patient as it would be for drugs to be subscribed by a doctor to make the patient feel better.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I mean, I think that assisted suicide would have been as unthinkable at the time this was enacted as prescribing cocaine just for recreational use.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But you agree -- you -- in answer to Justice Breyer's question, he mentioned a drug that was a schedule 1 drug, morphine.  Or maybe --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- perhaps it isn't --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: It's schedule 2 drug.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But are you saying that if the doctor is using it, saying, "In my medical judgment, this makes people happy; and, therefore, I'm going to prescribe it," that a State could permit that?  Wouldn't the Moore case rule that out?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But I thought the idea of Moore was, if you're using this, the doctor is prescribing the drug as a pusher.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, but let's -- but the supposition is that the State legal judgment is that that's the wrong characterization, that it's legitimate medical practice to make patients feel better, and morphine does that; and so, the State can allow them to prescribe morphine to make people feel better.  And I understand your position to be that that would be permissible?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: That could not -- that's not prohibited under the Controlled --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- Substances Act.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: And you say the Attorney General of the United States could not deem it to be drug abuse under the Act if a State allowed that for recreational use or to cure depression or -- How about steroids for bodybuilders? -- and decided that's perfectly okay.  Now, can the Attorney General find that that's drug abuse?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, I don't know that I understand your answer.  Could the Attorney General deem the authorization -- purported authorization by a physician to use morphine to help with depression, or steroids for bodybuilding -- can that Attorney General say, under the Act, that's drug abuse?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Suppose I disagreed with you about that, then would you lose the case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I'm asking, if I disagreed with you that I thought -- we take the facts of Moore, where he's a drug pusher, the doctor, and, for some unknown reason, the State says, "That's fine, it doesn't violate State law," but the Attorney General says, "Do what you want about State law.  I think it violates the Federal law."  Suppose I think the Attorney General does have the  right to do that for -- assuming it -- assuming it -- then what do you say about this case?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What does that do to the effectiveness of regulation under the Controlled Substances Act?  If one State can say it's legal for doctors to prescribe morphine to make people feel better, or to prescribe steroids for bodybuilding, doesn't that undermine the uniformity of the Federal law and make enforcement impossible?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, that may or --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- may not be true.  But focus on the particular question.  If you have one State that allows the use of a drug that the Federal Government has determined is illegal, and is illegal everywhere else because other States haven't done it, how is the Federal Government supposed to enforce that prohibition?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I'm trying to get at the specific enforcement point.  If you have one State that allows morphine to be used legally for --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- recreational  purposes, how is the Federal Government supposed to enforce the prohibition on that elsewhere?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But are you saying, in response to the Chief Justice's question, that, in fact, Congress, itself, could not explicitly pass a statute that says, "No State, through its doctors or otherwise, may authorize the use of morphine" --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: All right.  So, you're not making a --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- constitutional --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- argument.  You're sticking to your statutory argument.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Which comes down to an argument  that "accepted medical practice" means accepted medical practice State by State --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- rather than on some uniform basis.  Do you have any other area, regarding the enforcement of this Act, where the drug is allowed, or not allowed, to be used on the basis of divergent views of medical practice by divergent States?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Such as?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: In palliative care?  And you think in some States you can -- you can prescribe these drugs without violating the Act; whereas, in other States, the same prescription would violate the Act.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Would it violate the Federal law in those other States?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Oh.  So you say that in -- with respect to many aspects of this legislation, what's lawful -- and what's lawful depends upon the accepted medical practice within the State.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Does this have to be reflected in the State medical board determinations, or just in what the -- what the doctors in that region tend to think is a good idea?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Any cases that you can think of where the same prescription has been held okay in one State and not okay in another State?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Yes, but the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- statute goes beyond the State law, the five factors, you know, on the -- justify the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- revocation.  And some are in compliance with State law, but the fifth factor is, "such other conduct which may threaten the public health and safety."  It seems to me that's a clear grant of authority to go beyond State law.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, what do you do with regulation 1306, which -- the one that, of course, talks about "legitimate medical purpose"?  That was promulgated in 1971.  It wasn't directed to the Oregon statute.  And yet it suggests that the Attorney General has the authority to interpret that phrase.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: You had a --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- second answer?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I'm sorry.  You had a second answer?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Mr. Atkinson, you've spent most of your time talking about the statute and the regulations.  Do you also make the argument that ,even if the Government wanted to do this thing, it would be unconstitutional?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But why would it raise a significant constitutional question?  I take it that it's none of the Government's business whether people gamble or not.  I take it, it's none of the -- the Federal Government -- I take it, it's none of the Federal Government's business whether people are allowed to drink at 21 or at 18, innumerable other things, which really are matters that belong to the police power of the States. But the Federal Government has chosen to regulate those things through the use of its commerce power.  Is the drinking age any more a matter of -- or any less a matter of State privilege than suicide?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So, are those -- are those entries of the Federal Government into the regulation of drinking age, are they unconstitutional --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- or do they raise serious  -- constitutional questions?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, why does this one?  I don't --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, if ten States adopted assisted suicide, it might be a different -- a different

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- constitutional --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- question.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Would you spend a minute --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: The statute gives the Attorney General authority to promulgate regulations for the dispensing of drug -- 821 -- and that seems to me to describe precisely what the Attorney General has done here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, it seems to me --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- very odd to have a regulation on dispensing that takes no account of the purpose for which the drug is being used.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, but I give --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- you a statutory reference, and then you tell me about something else.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I'm sorry, on that, I didn't think that the reg was defining the word "dispense."  I thought the statute defines the word "dispense."  And it's -- persons registered by the AG to dispense controlled substances are exempt.  And then you look at who is such a person.  A person who does that is a practitioner.  And who is a practitioner?  A registered practitioner is one who prescribes, a physician registered by the United  States to distribute or dispense a controlled substance in the course of professional practice.  And I thought this reg is defining "in the course of professional practice." Am I wrong about that?  I thought it was a reg that says, "In the course of professional practice, the prescription, to be effective, must be a legitimate medical purpose by an individual practitioner."  Now, I might be wrong.  How does it work?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: On the matter of policy, I would -- since -- if you -- if you've said basically what you want to say in your argument, I would appreciate your devoting a minute to an assumption which you don't want to agree with.  But suppose I were to assume that a State is not free, through the device of defining what's good medical practice, to gut the Act -- that is, to really make marijuana or something else, like morphine, legal -- because they disagree with Congress's basic judgment that it should be illegal.  That could happen.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Now, suppose I think that the AG does have the power to stop Congress from gutting the  Act.  All right?  Now, on that, do I have -- if I believe that, on that assumption, do I have to decide this case against you?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And if not, why not?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Suppose, on the commerce-clause question, I -- on assumption, I don't agree with you, either -- then do I have to decide? [Laughter.]

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I would --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Far be it from me to suggest an argument that you don't want to make, but, I mean, I've  found it different, in life and law, when you pass a rule in a State that guts an Act, from when you pass the rule in a State that doesn't seem to have much to do with the purpose of the Act.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes, you would.  I think -- [Laughter.]

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It seems to me -- it seems to me that you -- that you cannot accept the premise that it guts the Act, if you come in here with the proposition, which you do, that what the Act says is: whatever is accepted medical practice within the State is okay. That's your principal point.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But the Act does not refer to any overall Federal accepted medical practice.  It refers to accepted medical practice, State by State.  And, therefore, it in no way guts the Act if a State wants to let these drugs be used for, you know, make-people-happy purposes.  I don't see how you can accept the premise.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: May I ask you, in -- Mr. Atkinson, in response to the question you were just asked, you said there were procedural problems, no notice in comment.  So, that's a "how" it's done.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: How about the "who"?  Is this something -- how does it work under the Controlled Substance Act?  What authority does the Department of HHS have?  What is the division of authority between those two under the Act?  The Attorney General, on the one hand, and the Department of Health and Human Services, and including the FDA, on the other.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But you made --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- you made a point earlier  that the Attorney General has never done this before, has never said, "You can't prescribe particular drugs for" -- has -- that has not been done.  You've been giving examples of where the FDA ruled that you can't --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- use a drug.  And that control is nationwide, no matter what the State medical board thinks, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Who -- the consultation, you said, was not with HHS, and it wasn't with Oregon?  Who did the Attorney General consult?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: May ask this question concerning the -- Justice Scalia's suggestion that you're  insisting the States would have the authority to act independently of a congressional prohibition against the use of a substance to make people happy and so forth. Isn't your point in this case that Congress hasn't really spoken to the issue to which the Attorney General has spoken?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Which is the opposite of the case that Justice Scalia point, where the Congress has spoken to the issue.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, but in 1971 Congress didn't assume the States were going to pass legislation for use of drugs to assist with suicide, either.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: These are all different manners of assisting people to stay alive or assisting people to feel better.  Assisting people to die is something of a totally different category.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I don't deny that.  I -- I'm not taking a position on whether, you know, a State wants to allow it, or not.  I'm just taking a position on whether it was envisioned by Congress, in 1971, that  accepted medical practice would include prescribing drugs to help somebody end his life.  And I don't think it -- I don't think it would have occurred to Congress.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But I take it you would agree that, in effect, all you need to win on the statutory argument is for us to accept the premise that Congress may very well have intended to interfere with the practice of medicine and to authorize the Attorney General to do it, insofar as the practice of medicine would have gutted the statute -- e.g., doctors who prescribe recreational drugs, doctors who, in effect, cater to pushers -- but that Congress did not intend to go any further than that in authorizing interference with the practice of medicine.  I take it you agree that if we accepted that premise, that would be sufficient for you in this case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Counsel. General Clement, you have four minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But what about gutting?  Never mind Mr. Atkinson's argument.  What about gutting?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: At the time --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- at the time this statute was passed to deal with lax State treatment of opium, was opium regulated as part of medical practice in  any of the States?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Was the impact profound because they were in what's now schedule 1, that they were just prohibited?  In other words, were doctors allowed to prescribe opium for some purposes?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: May I ask you this question? If the Attorney General determined that acupuncture was conduct that threatened the public health and safety,  could he de-license, or revoke, the license of doctors who engaged in acupuncture?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, General Clement. The case is submitted. [Whereupon, at 11:02 a.m., the case in the above-entitled matter was submitted.]
